  • 白宫：以色列必须区分平民和哈马斯武装分子
  • 英国和法国强调向加沙提供援助的重要性
  • 巴勒斯坦红新月会：又有 10 辆援助卡车从埃及抵达
  • 哈马斯军事部门称击中了两辆以色列坦克

以色列军方周日表示，以色列正在扩大在加沙的地面行动，其战斗机已经袭击了数百个哈马斯目标，总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡称这是一场为期三周的战争的第二阶段。

加沙的电话和互联网通信在长达一天多的停电后部分恢复，由于以色列袭击了控制该地区的激进哈马斯组织的目标，这严重影响了救援行动。

留在加沙城的公务员沙班·艾哈迈德说：“以色列切断了我们与世界的联系，以便消灭我们，但我们听到了爆炸声，我们很自豪抵抗战士在数米之外阻止了他们。”尽管以色列警告撤离南部。

艾哈迈德说，他周日才发现他的表弟因停电而在周五的空袭中丧生。

军方表示，以色列国防军 (IDF) 战斗机袭击了加沙地带哈马斯的 450 多个军事目标，包括作战指挥中心、观察哨和反坦克导弹发射站。

军方发言人丹尼尔·哈加里在简报中说：“我们正在逐步扩大地面活动和我们在加沙地带的部队范围。” “我们将从空中、海上和陆地上竭尽全力确保我们部队的安全并实现战争目标。”

自哈马斯武装分子在10月7日的跨境袭击中杀死至少1,400人并劫持200多人质以来，以色列加强了封锁并对加沙进行了三周的轰炸。

拥有230万人口的加沙地带的医疗当局周日表示，在以色列消灭伊朗支持的哈马斯武装分子的行动中，有8,005名巴勒斯坦人——其中包括3,324名未成年人——被杀。

西方国家普遍支持他们所说的以色列的自卫权。但国际社会对爆炸造成的人员伤亡越来越强烈，并呼吁“人道主义暂停”，以便向加沙平民提供援助。

白宫国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文告诉美国有线电视新闻网，以色列必须使用一切可能的手段区分加沙的巴勒斯坦平民和哈马斯武装分子，他还敦促内塔尼亚胡“遏制”极端犹太定居者针对被占领约旦河西岸无辜人民的暴力行为。

教皇方济各周日呼吁停火，并再次呼吁释放所有人质。

苏纳克办公室表示，英国首相苏纳克和法国总统马克龙在周日的电话中表达了他们对向加沙提供援助的担忧。

短缺

该组织表示，由于食品、水和药品供应不足，加沙大部分地区已化为废墟，数千名居民闯入联合国巴勒斯坦难民署（近东救济工程处）的仓库和配送中心，抢夺面粉和“基本生存物品”。星期日。

负责与巴勒斯坦人协调的以色列国防部机构 Cogat 的埃拉德·戈伦 (Elad Goren) 上校表示，以色列将允许在未来几天大幅增加对加沙的援助，巴勒斯坦平民应前往这片小领土南部的“人道主义区”。 。

巴勒斯坦红新月会周日表示，10 辆运载食品和药品的埃及卡车已通过拉法过境点抵达加沙，使目前总数达到 94 辆，仅占所需数量的一小部分。

住在加沙汗尤尼斯帐篷里的流离失所的巴勒斯坦人描述了恶劣的生活条件，几乎没有食物和水，上厕所要排队几个小时。

“我希望上帝怜悯我们，让战争停止，”父亲拉米·艾尔坎 (Rami Al-Erqan) 抱着他的女儿（他的六个孩子之一）说道。 “我们已经达到了一种希望死在废墟下只是为了休息的状态。我们的生活就是折磨。”

周日，以色列中部也遭到猛烈火箭袭击，几个主要城市拉响了警报。

哈马斯武装组织卡萨姆旅在其 Telegram 账户上表示，他们正在“轰炸特拉维夫，以回应犹太复国主义对平民的屠杀”。

他们后来说，他们的战士在加沙西北部与以色列军队发生冲突，并点燃了两辆以色列坦克。以色列没有立即就这些说法发表评论。

内塔尼亚胡周六警告以色列人，预计将有一场“漫长而艰难”的战役，但没有将目前对加沙的入侵称为入侵。美国官员称，美国总统乔·拜登的一些助手建议以色列同行暂缓立即发动全面进攻。

内塔尼亚胡还承诺将不遗余力释放哈马斯扣押的200多名人质，其中包括外国人。

抗议

这场冲突引发了世界各地支持巴勒斯坦人的大规模示威活动。周日，数千人在贝鲁特集会，表达对加沙的声援。

巴勒斯坦红新月会表示，已收到以色列当局的警告，要求立即撤离加沙地带的圣城医院，并补充说，周日进行的突袭行动发生在距该设施仅 50 米的地方。

红新月会表示，约有 14,000 人在医院寻求庇护，以躲避以色列的空袭。

以色列指责哈马斯将指挥中心和其他军事基础设施设在加沙医院，但该组织否认了这一点。

巴勒斯坦官员表示，约有 5 万人也在加沙希法医院避难，并表示他们担心以色列对该设施的持续威胁。

周五晚上，以色列向加沙派遣了部队和坦克，重点关注基础设施，包括哈马斯修建的广泛隧道网络。军方没有提供部署规模的详细信息。

以色列首席军事发言人拒绝透露以色列是否是电信中断的幕后黑手，但表示将采取必要措施来保护其军队。

一名自称是耶和华见证人前成员的男子因涉嫌参与周日在印度南部喀拉拉邦举行的该组织会议上引爆自制炸弹而被拘留，该炸弹造成两名妇女死亡、数十人受伤，警察说。

首席部长皮纳拉伊·维贾扬 (Pinarayi Vijayan) 在新闻发布会上告诉记者，第二名妇女死亡，并补充说，有 17 人在重症监护室，其中 5 人情况危急。

卫生部长 Veena George 早些时候告诉路透社，一名 95% 烧伤的 12 岁女孩也处于危急状态。

多米尼克·马丁 (Dominic Martin) 在 Facebook 上发布了一段视频，声称对此次袭击负责，并于中午后不久在距离爆炸现场约 40 公里（25 英里）的特里苏尔区警察局自首。

警察公共关系官员普拉莫德·库马尔告诉路透社：“多米尼克仍在科钦接受审问。他被我们拘留，但到目前为止我们还没有记录他的被捕情况。”

“我们仍在试图确定他的陈述的真实性，这需要一些时间。我们目前无法确认他是否参与此案，调查正在进行中，”他补充道。

这起事件发生在耶和华见证人在卡拉马瑟里举行大会期间，该大会位于科钦市东北约 10 公里（6 英里）处。

耶和华见证人地区发言人 TA Sreekumar 告诉路透社，马丁不是该组织的注册成员。他说大约有 2,300 人参加了为期三天的活动，但他不知道马丁是否在场。

斯里库马尔向路透社证实，该中心至少发生了两次大爆炸。

马丁在一段近六分钟的 Facebook 视频中说道：“我对此承担全部责任。炸弹爆炸是我进行的。我制作这段视频是为了清楚地表明我这样做的原因。”该视频在 Facebook 上发布了大约 4 小时。它消失了。

马丁说，大约六年前，他相信耶和华见证人的教义是“反民族的”，他曾试图与该组织讨论改变他们的观点。

喀拉拉邦警察局长谢克·达维什·萨赫布早些时候告诉记者，初步调查显示使用了简易爆炸装置。

首席部长维贾扬表示，警方正在认真对待这起事件，一个由 20 名成员组成的特别小组正在调查，他将在周一上午的全党会议上提供更多信息。

“作为当天活动的一部分，爆炸发生在祈祷结束后几秒钟。第一次爆炸发生在大厅中间。几秒钟后，大厅两侧同时发生了两起爆炸，”斯里库马尔早些时候告诉记者。 mathrubhumi.com，当地媒体。

耶和华见证人是一个国际基督教教派，于 1870 年左右在美国成立。他们以挨家挨户传福音而闻名于许多国家。

该组织称其在印度拥有约 6 万名追随者。

“气体浓度正常。没有明显的火灾迹象。”

英国首相苏纳克和法国总统马克龙周日在通话后表示，他们对向加沙提供援助以及以色列与哈马斯战争蔓延的风险表示担忧。

以色列军队扩大了在加沙的地面行动，同时他们的战斗机还袭击了数百个哈马斯目标，以色列称这是一场为期三周的战争的第二阶段。

自从本月初哈马斯枪手在以色列发动致命袭击并引发冲突以来，苏纳克和马克龙都访问了以色列及其邻国。

苏纳克发言人表示：“领导人强调了向加沙提供紧急人道主义援助的重要性。他们同意共同努力，为需要的人提供重要的食物、燃料、水和药品，并让外国人撤离。”说。

“他们对更广泛地区、特别是西岸局势升级的风险表示共同担忧。”

根据马克龙办公室的一份声明，领导人还重申了以色列在国际法范围内自卫的权利，以及找到释放哈马斯扣押人质的方法的重要性。

两位领导人都表示，长期停滞不前的两国解决方案，即为以色列人和巴勒斯坦人建立独立国家，是创造和平的最佳途径。

安德鲁·麦克阿斯基尔和米歇尔·罗斯报道 伯纳黛特·鲍姆和休·劳森编辑; Sun, 29 Oct 2023 15:21:32 GMT IQ5TFO2GTNLDXD6PL4YQMBSIR4 https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/britain-france-stress-need-get-aid-into-gaza-2023-10-29/Reuters以色列巴勒斯坦/英国法国（更新 1） 'Friends' star Matthew Perry dies of possible drowning at 54

演员马修·佩里 (Matthew Perry) 在 90 年代美国收视率最高的电视情景喜剧《老友记》中饰演爱说俏皮话的钱德勒·宾 (Chandler Bing)，深受人们喜爱，他于周六在热水浴缸中溺水身亡。他54岁了。

《洛杉矶时报》和 TMZ.com 援引执法部门消息称，这位美国加拿大籍表演者被发现死在洛杉矶家中的按摩浴缸中。播出了 10 年《老友记》的 NBC 在社交媒体平台 X 上发表声明，证实了他的去世。

这一消息引起了名人和其他知名人士的悲痛。

演员米拉·索维诺 (Mira Sorvino) 在 X 上说道：“哦不！！！马修·佩里！！你可爱的、烦恼的灵魂！愿你在天堂找到幸福，用你独特的智慧让大家开怀大笑！！！”

加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多是佩里在渥太华的前同学，他形容佩里的去世“令人震惊和悲伤”。

特鲁多在 X 节目中说道：“我永远不会忘记我们曾经在校园里玩的游戏，我知道世界各地的人们永远不会忘记他给他们带来的快乐。谢谢你带来的所有欢笑，马修。你被爱了。” ——我们会想念你的。”

NBC新闻援引佩里一位不愿透露姓名的代表和执法部门消息人士的话称，佩里被发现死在洛杉矶太平洋帕利塞兹附近的家中。

NBC 娱乐公司表示：“我们对马修·佩里的过早去世感到无比悲伤。” “他以完美的喜剧时机和诙谐的智慧为世界各地数亿人带来了如此多的欢乐。他的遗产将代代相传。”

佩里于 10 月 23 日在 Instagram 上发布的最后一篇帖子，其中包括一张他晚上坐在泳池或按摩浴缸中的照片，并写道：“哦，温暖的水流让你感觉良好？我是马特曼。”

佩里最出名的是他在国际上大获成功的《老友记》中长期扮演的钱德勒，该剧从 1994 年到 2004 年播出了 10 季，与詹妮弗·安妮斯顿、柯特妮·考克斯、大卫·休默、马特·勒布朗和丽莎·库卓共同主演。

该剧的六名演员都成为了国际名人，他们扮演了一群关系密切的年轻人，他们在彼此的公寓和虚构的曼哈顿咖啡馆“Central Perk”度过了时光。

主要故事情节之一涉及钱德勒和考克斯饰演的莫妮卡·盖勒之间的秘密恋情，其他四位朋友——瑞秋、乔伊、菲比和罗斯——都一一发现了这一点。两人最终结婚。

该剧组于 2021 年（即该剧大结局 17 年后）重聚，在 HBO Max 上播出了一部大肆宣传的特别节目。

该节目一度成为美国黄金时段收视率最高的电视节目，在其受欢迎程度最高时，每位演员每集收入达 100 万美元。

在最初的竞选过程中，佩里与处方药和酒精成瘾的长期斗争隐藏在公众视野之外，他在 2022 年的回忆录《朋友、情人和可怕的大事》中对此进行了详细描述。

“嗨，我的名字是马修，尽管你可能知道我的另一个名字。我的朋友们叫我马蒂。我应该死了，”佩里在书的开头写道。

在 2022 年 10 月发表的《纽约时报》采访中，佩里表示，他已经戒酒 18 个月了：“我可能花了 900 万美元或其他东西来试图保持清醒。”

佩里在他的书中讲述了他在拍摄钱德勒和莫妮卡婚礼的那一集后必须立即被送回戒毒所。

继《老友记》之后，佩里又出演了三部网络电视作品，但都被证明是短暂的——《日落大道上的 60 号工作室》、《阳光先生》和《继续前进》。

他还在其他热门电视节目中客串或反复出演角色，包括《白宫风云》、《甜心俏佳人》、《实习医生风云》和《比佛利山庄，90210》。他的电影作品包括《傻瓜冲进来》、《整个九码》、《几乎英雄》和《三人探戈》。

Fishermen in the Lebanese city of Tyre are among those counting the costs of war in the Middle East. As Israel and Hezbollah clash, it is too dangerous to sail into nearby fishing grounds.

"Already our fish were scarce. Now we have the war," said fisherman Imad Azuzu. "If we venture a little in the sea, we do so in fear."

His industry has been hit by the effects of the war that erupted on Oct. 7 between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas. The Lebanese Shi'ite group Hezbollah - a Hamas ally - has been trading fire with Israel at the border.

While clashes have so far been largely contained to the border, fishermen say they are only venturing a few miles from Tyre, where explosions from the fighting 20 km (12 miles) away can be heard.

"The (Lebanese) army has warned us against going to southern areas like Al Bayyada or Naqoura because it's dangerous. We are already afraid, the security situation is scary," said Adel Abde, another fisherman.

A Lebanese security source said the fishermen were allowed to fish normally in the Tyre area but not to approach floating barriers separating Lebanese and Israeli waters.

The fishing industry employees 2,000 people in Tyre, a centre of ancient civilisation from where the Phoenicians sailed all over the Mediterranean.

At the port near the old city, small fishing boats painted bright white were tied up as fishermen loaded fish into buckets and repaired nets.

The people of Tyre can ill afford more hardship. They and the rest of Lebanon were hit by the collapse of the country's financial system four years ago, which plunged many into poverty.

Fish and seafood production in Lebanon bring in $377 million a year, supporting more than 4,000 families, United Nations figures show.

Ibrahim Suwdan, who started fishing 40 years ago aged 10, said safety worries had deprived him of two weeks fishing - and income that would have helped get him through the winter.

The fishing boats were not putting to sea, he said, "Because people are afraid."

The head of self-driving auto technologies firm Mobileye (MBLY.O) and one of Israel's leading businessmen, Amnon Shashua, on Sunday urged the immediate ouster of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government.

"We must cut our losses and do it quickly. The only solution to the current situation in Israel is to replace the government, and it needs to happen immediately," Shashua wrote in an opinion piece in financial daily Calcalist.

Netanyahu caused his own uproar on Sunday by taking a jab at his intelligence chiefs, saying they never warned him Hamas was planning its attack, but later retracted his comments and issued an apology.

Netanyahu's office, asked by Reuters, declined to comment on Shashua's editorial.

The government, Shashua said, which seemed more concerned about its political survival than "the good of the country," could be replaced without calling a new election, minimizing political turmoil, with the formation of a new coalition within the current parliament.

Netanyahu has not taken responsibility over intelligence and operational failures, saying only that there would be time to ask tough questions, including of himself, after the war.

Israeli officials have said events leading up to and including the handling of the Hamas attack would be investigated, but that the current focus was on the conflict.

Maldives will work to return Indian military personnel from its shores "as soon as possible," President-elect Mohamed Muizzu told Reuters on Sunday, insisting it was the top foreign policy priority for the tiny Indian Ocean island chain.

Muizzu won Maldives' presidential election last month, beating incumbent President Ibrahim Solih in a second-round runoff.

Solih had followed an "India first" policy but Muizzu in his election campaign promised to remove a small Indian military presence of some 75 personnel in Maldives.

"I will be holding frank and detailed diplomatic consultations with India to work out details of sending back military personnel from the Maldives as soon as possible," Muizzu, who will take office on Nov. 17, told Reuters in an online interview from Male.

"The focus is not on the actual number of military personnel here, it is on not having any at all in the Maldives. We will discuss with the Indian government and find out a way forward for this."

Home to about 521,000 people, Maldives is famous for its sun-kissed atolls and luxury tourist resorts.

Rival Asian giants India and China have both invested millions of dollars in infrastructure in the islands as they seek to build influence.

The coalition backing Muizzu is known to be close to China but Muizzu told Reuters he was not pro-China or anti any country.

India has longstanding cultural, financial and security ties with Maldives, and has denied it aims to establish a military presence in the islands.

Muizzu said he will seek details of an agreement signed with India to build a naval harbour for Maldivian forces, to clear up any concerns over Maldivian independence and sovereignty.

"Of course we need development of the naval base and other military training grounds in the country with assistance from different countries but it doesn't mean there should be a setup in which foreign military presence is required for its operations," Muizzu told Reuters.

He said he would make it a priority to ensure that his country's relations with India thrive.

"So I'm sure our friends in the Indian leadership will agree that we have a shared interest in creating a reservoir of respect which will be beneficial not just for the Maldives and India, but also for the stability and security of the Indian Ocean region as well."

Muizzu also plans to improve ties with China, which has in recent years invested in infrastructure projects as it builds closer ties and pursues its Belt and Road vision of transport and energy networks.

Maldives will engage with India and China, as well as other countries, on growth opportunities including investment in special economic zones Muizzu expects to establish to spur growth and double tourism numbers during his five-year term.

"I'm not pro-China or any country. The Maldives is and will not be anti or pro any country. My government will always be for Maldives. The Maldives will benefit immensely from having strong and vibrant relationships with the advanced economies as well as with emerging economic powers," he said.

Gazans searched for loved ones and heard news of family members killed as communications gradually returned to the enclave on Sunday after a near total blackout as Israel's troops and armour pushed into the Hamas-ruled enclave.

The United Nations also warned that Palestinians were desperate for food and that civil order was breaking down after three weeks of war with Hamas militants and a siege on the densely populated coastal strip.

The fighting intensified on Friday night as Israeli forces waged ground operations in Gaza in what Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described as the second phase of the war aimed at crushing Hamas.

Shaban Ahmed, a public servant who works as an engineer and has five children, described the Israeli attacks as "doomsday".

"This morning, Sunday, I discovered that my cousin has been killed in an air strike on their house on Friday," Ahmed, who stayed in Gaza City despite an Israeli warning to evacuate south, told Reuters.

"We only knew today. Israel cut us off from the world in order to wipe us out, but we are hearing the sounds of explosions and we are proud the resistance fighters have stopped them at meters distance."

Israel's chief military spokesperson has declined to say whether Israel was behind the telecommunications blackout but said it would do what it needed to protect its forces.

Israeli air strikes have been pounding Gaza City since Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on southern Israel, in which Israeli authorities said at least 1,400 Israelis were killed in the deadliest day of the nation's 75-year history.

Ahmed said the strikes on Friday from air, sea and the ground continued non-stop for hours.

Hamas said on Sunday it was continuing to confront Israeli forces, which were continuing ground operations.

The health ministry in Gaza said on Sunday a total of 8,005 people there had been killed since Oct. 7.

CIVIL ORDER

Palestinians were struggling to find loved ones in the bloody chaos as the growing humanitarian crisis squeezed Gaza. One woman looking for one of her sons stood over rubble in Gaza City and cried out: "I don't know where he is."

In another part of Gaza, people looked for survivors after Israeli air strikes in the Al-Nasir neighbourhood.随着浓烟滚滚，人们从废墟中拉出一具尸体。一个女人尖叫起来。 Others carried the injured.

Many people have been glued to rusty radios for news, which had become the only means to get information on the heaviest Israeli air strikes ever on narrow Gaza, one of the most densely populated spots in the world, with the internet and phones down.

Medical services became so stretched that ambulances were no longer taking calls. People hit by bombings relied on volunteers to take them for treatment.

The air strikes focused heavily on areas in northern Gaza, including Gaza City, where ground incursions were taking place.

People in the southern Gaza Strip said they heard the explosions and saw the sky light up - but had no means of checking on family and friends in the targeted areas.

“Gaza is isolated from the rest of the world. Strikes are hitting right next to us, around us and no one can reach us or locate the strike," said Gaza resident Um Yehia, who went south after the Israeli warning and is now sheltering inside the Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis.

Bilal Abu Mostafa's barber shop was destroyed two weeks ago. Like many Gazans he has taken shelter in a hospital, where doctors are struggling to keep pace with casualties.

He turned a damaged ambulance into a makeshift barber shop.

After dark he goes up into a hospital room to give hair cuts to "people severely burned or broken and can't come downstairs".

'WE WILL REMAIN STEADFAST'

Aid supplies to Gaza have been choked since Israel began bombarding the enclave in response the Hamas attacks, and the communications isolation also hit aid agencies, complicating already severe shortages of food, fuel and medicine.

The Palestinian Red Crescent said on Sunday it received 10 trucks from the Egyptian Red Crescent through the Rafah crossing, containing food supplies and medical supplies, bringing the total to 94.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday took a jab at his intelligence chiefs on the X platform, saying they never warned him Hamas was planning its wide-scale attack on Oct. 7 , but later retracted his comments and issued an apology.

The remarks, posted on X at 1 am on Sunday (around 2300 GMT on Saturday), caused a political uproar and a rift within the war cabinet of Netanyahu, who has drawn public ire for not taking responsibility over intelligence and operational failures relating to Hamas' rampage through southern Israel.

While top officials - from the heads of the military and the Shin Bet domestic spy service to his finance minister - have all acknowledged their failures, Netanyahu has not.

He has only said that there would be time to ask tough questions, including of himself, after the war.

Israel's military spokesperson, asked about Netanyahu's comments during a daily briefing with reporters, declined to respond, saying: "We are now at war, focused on the war."

Israeli officials have said events leading up to and including the handling of the Hamas attack itself would be investigated, but that the current focus was on the conflict.

Netanyahu's now-deleted post had said: "At no time and no stage was a warning given to Prime Minister Netanyahu regarding war intentions of Hamas. On the contrary, all security officials, including the head of army intelligence and the head of the Shin Bet, estimated that Hamas was deterred and interested in an arrangement."

In a second post on X about 10 hours later, Netanyahu wrote: "I was wrong," adding that his remarks "should not have been made and I apologize for that."

"I give full backing to all the heads of the security branches," he said.

Netanyahu's initial comments were promptly rebuked by current and past allies, including Benny Gantz, a former defense minister who is now in Netanyahu's war cabinet.

Gantz said on X that Netanyahu should retract what he said and let the matter go.

"When we are at war, leadership must show responsibility, decide to do the right things and bolster the forces in a way that they can carry out what we demand of them," Gantz said.

The well-planned surprise Hamas attack was the deadliest for Israel in its 75-year history. Israel has since bombarded the Gaza Strip with devastating air strikes and begun ground operations with the aim of toppling the Iran-backed Islamist group and securing the release of scores of people abducted from Israel to Gaza on Oct. 7.

Opposition leader Yair Lapid, who was formerly prime minister, said Netanyahu "crossed a red line" with the overnight post.

"The attempts to evade responsibility and place the blame on the security establishment weakens the IDF (Israel Defense Forces) while it's fighting Israel's enemies," he said.

Yossi Cohen, who headed the Mossad spy agency under previous Netanyahu governments, told Israel Radio: "You take responsibility from the beginning of your job, not from the middle."
